variant.question: After refueling procedure, the pilot notices that the amount of fuel in the tanks is about 2 900 kg over the amount considered for performance calculations. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Performance calculations must be redone, and aircraft and runway conditions must be within limits in order for the flight to safely continue.
Check that the Zero fuel mass is still within limits and carry on with the operation.
Defueling procedure must always be performed in such case.
Adding extra fuel will not have a great impact on performance and, therefore, the pilot is free to continue the operation.

variant.question: The French Safety Board (BEA) published a preliminary report of a serious incident involving an Airbus A330 being operated as a commercial air transport flight at Sidney, Australia. The Report states: "During take-off, a section of engine cowling from the NO. 1 engine separated from the aircraft. The crew conducted a fuel dump and returned the aircraft to Sydney." The incident did NOT involve an engine fire. What is the most appropriate explanation for why the crew dumped fuel after take-off?

options.text: They had to reduce the aircraft's mass in order to safely land below the maximum landing mass.
They made a mistake: According to normal procedures, the aircraft should have landed with all the remaining usable fuel.
They had to mitigate against the risk of fire and therefore empty the fuel tanks as much as possible.
After take-off, it is a normal procedure to dump some fuel in order to reduce pollution.

variant.question: You take-off from London Heathrow and experience an onboard emergency requiring you to dump fuel.  What actions would you take?

options.text: Go to the Bristol Channel to dump at not less than 6000 ft
Go to the Bristol Channel to dump at not less than 5000 ft.
Immediately dump fuel.
Land overweight

variant.question: An Air France airplane for a flight back to Paris takes off from Sydney and encounters an engine failure. The pilots have to jettison fuel before landing. Why?

options.text: To reduce the landing mass.
To increase the climb performance in case of a go around.
To empty the tanks and minimize the risk in case of a fire.
To keep the aircraft balanced.

variant.question: What is the most important factor determining the success of the Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) when dealing with the survival of passengers, crew and aircraft after an emergency landing?

options.text: The training of the RFFS
Number of fire extinguishers on board the aircraft
Number of engines on the aircraft
Equipment used to remove the aircraft from the runway

variant.question: When an aircraft is refuelling with passengers embarking, on board or disembarking it is necessary to:

options.text: Have ground equipment positioned so that if necessary an evacuation can be carried out with all doors available.
Have fire services vehicles manned at their station.
Have all doors open.
Have fire services parked by the aircraft.

variant.question: Concerning a possible fuel fire, what has to be done when ground servicing an aircraft?

options.text: There has to be a sufficient number of fire fighting equipment readily available at the aircraft to fight the fire at least initially.
There has to be sufficient number of fire fighting equipment readily available at the aircraft to fight the fire totally.
The fire fighters have to manned in their base in fire trucks to ensure fast arrival in case of fire.
The fire fighters have to be present at the location of the aircraft within in their vehicles.

variant.question: Which of the following is necessary during the ground servicing of an aircraft with regard to the possible event of a fuel fire?

options.text: Fire extinguishing equipment suitable for at least initial intervention in the event of a fuel fire and personnel trained in its use shall be readily available.
The rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be positioned at the aircraft in order to be available in the event of a fire.
Fire extinguishing equipment suitable for a total intervention in the event of a fuel fire and personnel trained in its use shall be readily available.
The rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be manned and at their stations in order to be available in the event of a fire.

variant.question: The principal objective of a rescue and fire fighting service at an aerodrome is to:

options.text: save lives.
respond within 2 minutes.
respond within 3 minutes.
preserve aircraft.

variant.question: What is required for the refuelling process with passengers on board of the aircraft?

options.text: Positioning of ground equipment to allow the use of a sufficient number of exits for an expeditious evacuation.
Fire extinguishing equipment and trained personal, suitable for an exhaustive fire fighting procedure shall be positioned as close as possible to the aircraft.
Fire services are in position ready for an event of fuel fire.
All aircraft doors must be open.

variant.question: According to ICAO Annex 14, which of the following is necessary when aircraft refuelling operations take place at the same time as passengers are embarking, on board or disembarking?

options.text: Ground equipment shall be positioned so as to allow the use of a sufficient number of exits for expeditious evacuation.
Rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be manned and at their stations in order to be available in the event of a fire.
Rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be positioned at the aircraft in order to be available in the event of a fire.
All exits from the aircraft must be open for an expeditious evacuation in the event of a fire.

variant.question: An aircraft lands at the destination with less than 30 minutes fuel. This is reported as:

options.text: Serious Incident.
As long as the aircraft land safely, there is no need to report.
Accident.
Incident.

variant.question: One of the most important factors bearing on effective rescue in a survivable aircraft accident is

options.text: the received training of the firefighters.
the size of the recovery and rescue machines and tools.
the number of available fire extinguishers.
the speed of the firetrucks.

variant.question: During flight, a low fuel alert suddenly appears, and the commander initiates an emergency diversion to an alternate airport. During the landing roll, a tire deflates. After parking, it is noted that the fuel remaining is below the required 30 minute final reserve. What has occurred?

options.text: A serious incident.
A serious accident.
An incident.
An accident.

variant.question:
During a Commercial Air Transport flight under IFR with a jet aeroplane, a warning by the fuel low level alarm was triggered. The flight crew declares an emergency and lands safely. During the landing roll, a tyre deflates. After coming to a stop, the crew cancels the distress message.
The fuel quantity measured by the Safely Investigation Authority is less than the final reserve (30 min).According to Regulation (EU) No 996/2010, this event is...

options.text: Serious incident.
Serious accident.
An accident.
An incident.

variant.question:
Rescue and fire-fighting (emergency) services provision is categorized according to physical characteristics of the type of aeroplane using the aerodrome
This classification is based upon

options.text: aeroplane overall length and fuselage width.
maximum number of passengers and crew.
Maximum Landing Mass and maximum number of passengers.
aeroplane length and Maximum Take-off Mass.
